questions.text: A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 6-hour history of persistent vertigo and nausea. She has been unable to walk due to dizziness and has vomited once since this morning. She has no history of similar symptoms and no recent trauma. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and drinks one to two glasses of wine on weekends. Medications are lisinopril, metformin, and simvastatin. She appears uncomfortable. She is alert and fully oriented. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 132/87 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows normal strength and sensation in all extremities. Reflexes are 2+ throughout. She sways towards the right side when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is able to fixate her eyes on a stable point while her head is rotated. There is vertical nystagmus that persists on gaze fixation of the right eye. Otoscopic examination shows normal tympanic membranes bilaterally. She is able to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears and to repeat words whispered in her ears bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Audiometry is more sensitive than a bedside examination in the diagnosis of hearing loss and would be performed if a peripheral cause of AVS such as labyrinthitis is suspected. Audiometry is not the most appropriate initial test if a central AVS is suspected. Hearing loss is usually absent in central AVS; it is only seen with certain rare causes of central AVS such as anterior inferior cerebellar artery stroke.

B) CORRECT:

Patients who have at least one finding consistent with a central AVS on the HINTS examination (i.e. vertical, torsional, or gaze-evoked nystagmus, a negative head impulse test, a positive skew deviation test) should undergo an MRI of the brain. Given the sudden onset of symptoms and the presence of multiple risk factors for a cerebrovascular accident, a stroke affecting the cerebellum or brainstem is the most likely cause of central AVS in this patient. Concomitant focal neurological deficits would indicate a central AVS but these deficits may not be present in inferior or midline cerebellar infarcts or lacunar brainstem lesions due to small vessel disease. If central AVS is suspected but the initial MRI is inconclusive (which can be the case for several hours after onset of AVS due to stroke), repeat MRIs should be performed.

Demyelinating diseases of the CNS (e.g., multiple sclerosis) are a cause of central AVS in young adults and are associated with a more gradual progression of symptoms when compared to AVS due to stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

A Dix-Hallpike maneuver is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), a peripheral cause of vertigo and nystagmus. This patient's HINTS examination is consistent with a central cause for the patient's symptoms, for which a different test is indicated. Moreover, in BPPV, the symptoms occur in episodes that last seconds to minutes, not hours.
Image Description:

A testing procedure used in patients with episodic triggered vertigo to evaluate for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

Starting in an upright seated position, the patient's head is rapidly rotated 45 degrees towards one side. Maintaining this degree of rotation, the patient is then quickly reclined and their head extended slightly below the end of the examination table (∼ 20 degrees). While holding this position, the examiner observes for 20–30 seconds for nystagmus and inquires regarding vertigo symptoms. The procedure is then repeated with the head rotated in the opposite direction. The test is positive (confirming BPPV) if the maneuver triggers nystagmus and/or vertigo during the observation period.

The Dix-Hallpike test with head rotation to the right tests the right posterior semicircular canal and the left anterior semicircular canal (and vice versa).
Illustrated here are the movements of the otoconia during the maneuver (black dots and arrows) and the upbeat nystagmus with an ipsiversive torsional component (i.e., the eye beats toward the forehead and the upper pole of the eye beats toward the affected ear), which represents a typical finding in posterior semicircular canal BPPV (present in approx. 95% of all patients with). In posterior canal BPPV, a positive result should only occur when the affected ear is turned towards the floor (unless BPPV is bilateral).

In anterior canal BPPV (rare), the nystagmus is downbeat instead (while maintaining the ipsiversive torsional component), and lateralization is less reliable (even in unilateral BPPV, testing either side may elicit nystagmus).

D) INCORRECT:

Caloric testing was used in the past to differentiate between central and peripheral AVS, but it is no longer used because it is cumbersome, less accurate than the HINTS test, and can worsen vertigo during testing. This patient's HINTS examination already indicates a central AVS. A different diagnostic test that can further characterize the central etiology of this patient's AVS is required.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with features of central AVS, a lumbar puncture (LP) could be considered if multiple sclerosis (MS) is suspected based on the clinical presentation (e.g., in a young adult who has gradually progressing symptoms) but imaging shows no evidence of MS. The patient's smoking history, comorbidities (hypertension, dyslipidemia, diabetes mellitus), and sudden symptom onset suggest a different cause of the central AVS, for which LP is not indicated.
questions.hint: The combination of acute nausea, imbalance, and vertigo is concerning for acute vestibular syndrome (AVS). The Head Impulse, Nystagmus, and Test of Skew (HINTS) exam is used to differentiate between central and peripheral causes of AVS. This patient's negative head impulse test and vertical nystagmus are consistent with a central cause of AVS.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man reports a one-day history of acute vertigo characterized by a sensation of spinning. His mental status and reflexes are normal, and his motor and cranial-nerve examinations are unremarkable.
Which one of the following additional historical features or physical examination findings would indicate a central, rather than a peripheral, cause of this patient’s vertigo?

choices.text: Recurrent episodes of vertigo lasting less than one minute each
Nystagmus that changes direction and does not suppress with visual fixation
A 30-second episode of nystagmus on Dix-Hallpike maneuver

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peripheral vertigo is also frequently acute in onset, especially in the case of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). A history of recurrent brief episodes of vertigo — and vertigo and mixed torsional and upbeat nystagmus elicited by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver — is consistent with BPPV.

B) INCORRECT:

Tinnitus may occur with both central and peripheral vertigo but is more suggestive of a peripheral etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Hearing impairment may occur with both central and peripheral vertigo but is more suggestive of a peripheral etiology.

D) CORRECT:

Peripheral vertigo and central vertigo may occur in similar patient populations. Differentiating between potential etiologies based on historical features and examination findings can be difficult.

Central vertigo is often acute in onset, may be milder, and is characterized by persistent symptoms. The presence of other neurologic abnormalities on examination — including cranial-nerve abnormalities, motor or sensory changes, and dysmetria or ataxia — suggests a diagnosis of central vertigo. Nystagmus that changes direction with gaze and persists with visual fixation raises suspicion for a central etiology. Nystagmus resulting from a central etiology may be horizontal, vertical, or torsional. Vascular risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus should also raise suspicion for a central etiology, such as transient ischemic attack or stroke.

Peripheral vertigo is also frequently acute in onset, especially in the case of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The nystagmus seen with peripheral vertigo typically suppresses with visual fixation and often does not change direction with changing gaze. A history of recurrent brief episodes of vertigo — and vertigo and mixed torsional and upbeat nystagmus elicited by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver — is consistent with BPPV.

The HINTS examination for stroke in acute vestibular syndrome can be helpful in differentiating central versus peripheral etiologies of vertigo in the acute phase. The examination consists of the three components detailed below and is valid only when the patient is actively experiencing vertigo.

• Head Impulse: With the patient’s gaze fixed on an object in the distance, quickly turn the patient’s head 10 degrees in either direction. A normal result is the absence of catch-up saccade, which is also found in central vertigo. A corrective saccade (eyes turning with head and then returning to the distant object) is expected with peripheral causes.
• Nystagmus: Vertical, torsional, and bidirectional nystagmus suggests a central cause. Spontaneous unidirectional horizontal nystagmus suggests a peripheral cause.
• Test of Skew: With the patient looking straight ahead, alternate between covering and uncovering each eye. A vertical change in position of a covered eye after being uncovered is abnormal and suggests a central lesion.

Key learning point: Direction-changing nystagmus that does not suppress with visual fixation is a feature that suggests a diagnosis of central vertigo.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral vertigo is also frequently acute in onset, especially in the case of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). A history of recurrent brief episodes of vertigo — and vertigo and mixed torsional and upbeat nystagmus elicited by the Dix-Hallpike maneuver — is consistent with BPPV.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension reports for evaluation of multiple concerns. He reports that he developed an upper respiratory tract infection 10 days ago, followed by a blocked-up feeling with reduced hearing in his right ear that did not respond to decongestants. Two days ago, he had nausea with vomiting, which is slowly resolving. Since then, he has had persistent vertigo. He notes new onset of a high-pitched noise in his right ear.
He has no history of head or neck trauma and reports no prior history of hearing loss or tinnitus. He has not traveled in 2 months. He is presently taking lisinopril and chondroitin sulfate.
His vital signs are normal, and he is not orthostatic. He appears well. His cardiovascular and neurologic examinations, including cranial nerves II-VII and IX-XII, are normal. His pharynx is mildly erythematous, with no tonsillitis. There is no lymphadenopathy. His ear canals are clear of cerumen. His Rinne test is positive bilaterally, and his Weber test lateralizes to the left. He has left-beating horizontal nystagmus that is worse on right lateral gaze.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ménière disease is characterized by fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, aural fullness, and recurrent severe vertigo with nausea and vomiting that lasts 30 minutes to many hours. Between episodes, the patient’s balance is normal. Typically, patients are older than age 50 with slowly progressing tinnitus and deafness in one ear (or, rarely, both) who suddenly develop severe vertigo that worsens over several minutes.

B) CORRECT:

The symptom of vertigo is defined as an illusion of movement of self or surroundings. The absence of any noted weakness, impaired speech, or diplopia in this patient makes a peripheral cause of vertigo — such as benign positional vertigo, labyrinthitis, vestibular neuritis, recurrent vestibulopathy, or drug effects — most likely.

The Rinne test is performed by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid process until sound is no longer heard; the fork is then immediately placed just outside the ear. In a normal ear, air conduction is better than bone conduction, and the patient can therefore hear the sound again when the tuning fork is moved from the mastoid process (bone) to outside the ear (air); this is known as a positive Rinne test.

In the Weber test, the tuning fork is placed in the middle of the skull, and the patient determines on which side the sounds can be heard most clearly. In this patient, the Weber test lateralizes to the left ear, which is consistent with sensorineural hearing loss on the right, a feature of labyrinthitis.

Labyrinthitis, the most likely diagnosis for this patient, is a peripheral vertigo associated with hearing loss that typically develops after a systemic viral illness. Nausea and vomiting are present when the labyrinthitis is severe. Tinnitus can also be seen. On examination, the patient will have a positive Rinne test bilaterally with better air conduction than bone conduction. The Weber test will lateralize to the ear with normal hearing, consistent with sensorineural hearing loss of the ear affected by the labyrinthitis. Patients may have a positive head-thrust test and nystagmus that does not change direction and is directed toward the uninvolved ear.

Key learning point: Labyrinthitis can be distinguished from vestibular neuritis by examining the patient’s hearing. Auditory function is preserved in patients with vestibular neuritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Many drugs may affect the inner ear. Most affect both vestibular and cochlear mechanisms, but the degree varies. Aspirin, for example, primarily affects cochlear function; high doses produce bilateral tinnitus and hearing loss without much vertigo. Common toxins include aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, cytotoxic agents, anticonvulsants, and alcohol. This patient’s medications — lisinopril and chondroitin — are not associated with vertigo.

D) INCORRECT:

Vestibular neuritis (vestibular neuronitis) is peripheral vertigo without hearing loss; it is secondary to inflammation of the eighth cranial nerve's vestibular segment. The patient has sudden onset of severe, constant vertigo that is exacerbated by head movement and that resolves over days to weeks. The patient may complain of fullness in the ear or tinnitus. The patient may have had an upper respiratory infection in the preceding 2 to 3 weeks. The symptoms may last days.

E) INCORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is the most common cause of vertigo. In contrast to viral labyrinthitis, BPPV tends to be acute in onset, without hearing loss, and is associated with episodic vertigo that is triggered by head turning. The dizziness typically lasts less than a minute and can be accompanied by nausea.

Appearance: alert; visibly uncomfortable
HEENT: PERRLA; spontaneous horizontal nystagmus in the right eye with the fast phase beating toward the left; nystagmus disappears when the patient looks to the right; no vertical misalignment on the alternate cover test; impaired vestibuloocular reflex in the right eye; external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane are intact bilaterally; Rinne test positive bilaterally; Weber test lateralized to the left

Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: nondistended; nontender to palpation
Neurologic: fully oriented; normal muscle tone; no tremors; sensation to light touch and temperature intact; muscle strength 5/5 throughout; mild gait ataxia



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Labyrinthitis, a subtype of vestibular neuritis, is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and AVS from a peripheral cause. This condition is caused by inflammation of the membranous labyrinth that is usually idiopathic, autoimmune, or caused by a viral (e.g., following an upper respiratory infection) or bacterial infection (e.g., as a complication of otitis media). Labyrinthitis causes decreased vestibular activity and typically manifests with nystagmus toward the healthy ear. Diagnosis is clinical and does not routinely require neuroimaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Bradyarrhythmia or tachyarrhythmia resulting from pacemaker failure can lead to dizziness as a result of presyncope. However, this patient has a normal heart rate with a regular rhythm. Moreover, presyncope usually lasts seconds to minutes and is not associated with nystagmus, nausea, or vomiting. This patient's presentation is consistent with dizziness due to vertigo.

C) INCORRECT:

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a peripheral cause of vertigo. However, episodes of BPPV are typically sudden, brief (< 1 minute), and triggered by certain head movements. Moreover, hearing loss is not expected in BPPV.

D) INCORRECT:

An ischemic stroke affecting the posterior circulation can cause vertigo. However, an ischemic stroke causes central vertigo, which manifests with a normal head impulse test, central-type nystagmus (e.g., direction-changing, vertical, or torsional nystagmus), or skew deviation on the HINTS examination. This patient has a peripheral cause for vertigo.

E) INCORRECT:

Wernicke encephalopathy can occur in patients with a history of heavy alcohol use and manifests with ataxia and features of oculomotor dysfunction such as horizontal nystagmus. However, this condition typically causes gaze-evoked nystagmus in both eyes, unlike the spontaneous unilateral nystagmus in this patient. Moreover, hearing loss is not expected in Wernicke encephalopathy, and the patient does not present with other clinical features of this condition such as disorientation, impaired vigilance, and cognitive deficits.
questions.hint: The presence of gait instability, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting indicate that vertigo due to acute vestibular syndrome (AVS) is the most likely cause of this patient's acute-onset dizziness. The presence of all of the following on HINTS examination strongly suggests peripheral vertigo: spontaneous unidirectional horizontal nystagmus, absent skew deviation, and abnormal head impulse test (i.e., impaired vestibuloocular reflex).

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic with dizziness and nausea during car rides. He often becomes pale, diaphoretic, and occasionally vomits if traveling more than 30 minutes. His parents are planning a 6-hour road trip and seek help to prevent his symptoms. He has no significant past medical history, takes no regular medications, and has no known drug allergies. On examination, he is afebrile and well-hydrated.
Which medication is the most appropriate prophylaxis for his motion sickness?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Motion sickness results from a sensory mismatch between visual and vestibular inputs, activating the vestibular nuclei and central vomiting pathway. Diphenhydramine, a first-generation H1 receptor blocker, has anticholinergic properties that inhibit vestibular signal transmission to the brain. Its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and affect central histaminergic and cholinergic receptors makes it effective for preventing motion sickness in pediatric patients.

Key learning point: Diphenhydramine, an antihistamine, is effective for treating motion sickness in children, while ondansetron and granisetron are not typically used for this purpose.

B) INCORRECT:

Ondansetron, a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, is effective for chemotherapy and postoperative nausea by blocking serotonin receptors. However, motion sickness involves cholinergic and histaminic pathways, making anticholinergic and antihistaminic medications more suitable.

C) INCORRECT:

Granisetron, a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, is used for chemotherapy-induced and postoperative nausea by blocking serotonin receptors. It lacks significant anticholinergic or antihistaminic properties, which are crucial for addressing the vestibular system's role in motion sickness.

D) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist with prokinetic properties, used for gastroparesis and certain nausea types. It does not target the cholinergic and histaminergic pathways involved in motion sickness and poses a risk of extrapyramidal side effects in children.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with diabetes and hypertension presents with acute onset continuous vertigo and vomiting that started 4 hours ago. She has no hearing loss or tinnitus. Examination shows horizontal nystagmus that changes direction with gaze, normal head impulse test with maintained central fixation, and vertical ocular misalignment on test of skew. The patient's gait is wide-based, but she can walk independently. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Administer meclizine and discharge home with ENT follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Caloric testing assesses peripheral vestibulopathy but is not appropriate in the acute setting if HINTS examination suggests central vertigo requiring urgent stroke evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of normal head impulse test, direction-changing nystagmus, and positive skew deviation constitutes abnormal HINTS examination, which strongly suggests central vertigo. In addition, this patient has stroke risk factors (age ≥ 65 years, diabetes, hypertension), making urgent neuroimaging with MRI brain the most appropriate next step.

C) INCORRECT:

Vestibular rehabilitation is used for peripheral vertigo conditions and chronic vestibular dysfunction. Immediate evaluation for central causes is required before considering any rehabilitation measures.

D) INCORRECT:

The Dix-Hallpike test is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo in patients with episodic, triggered vertigo. This patient presents with acute vestibular syndrome (continuous vertigo) and abnormal HINTS examination, suggesting central pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Meclizine and discharge are inappropriate because the HINTS examination findings are strongly suggestive of central vertigo, which requires immediate evaluation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with hypertension and diabetes presents with 6 hours of continuous vertigo that began while watching television. She reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. She denies recent head trauma, headache, or hearing changes. She has difficulty walking but can stand with support. Physical examination shows normal vital signs. Neurological examination shows horizontal nystagmus that beats to the left when looking left and to the right when looking right. Head impulse testing shows normal vestibuloocular reflex bilaterally. Cover-uncover testing shows vertical ocular misalignment. No other focal neurological deficits are identified. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate given the abnormal HINTS examination findings. The presence of direction-changing nystagmus, normal head impulse test, and skew deviation suggests central vertigo requiring urgent evaluation and neuroimaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic treatment with vestibular suppressants is inappropriate because the abnormal HINTS findings are suggestive of central vertigo. The priority is urgent neuroimaging to evaluate for stroke or other central pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo in patients with episodic, positionally triggered vertigo. This patient has acute vestibular syndrome with HINTS findings suggestive of central vertigo.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Early detection of a hemorrhagic stroke is essential; although MRI is able to detect both hemorrhagic and ischemic strokes, it is generally more difficult to obtain than a CT and may result in delays in diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Although MRI is the definitive imaging modality to evaluate for posterior fossa ischemic strokes, a hemorrhagic stroke should be ruled out first.
